ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about a wide variety of numerical methods and how implement them in code using Julia. Among the computational tools we covered: root-finding, minimization, interpolation, numerical integration, and dynamic programming. I also learned how to apply these tools to solve a bunch of interesting economic models. I think I got a little taste of what graduate studies in economics might look like.

Computation methods for differentiation, root-finding, optimization, interpolation, and integration, with an emphasis on dynamic programming and invariant distributions. Applications of these methods to economic models.
I learned computational methods in Julia (Bellman iteration, Gauss-Hermite quadrature, among other methods).
Root-finding, linear interpolation, cubic-spline interpolation, dynamic programming
Quite a good deal about dynamic programming and just numerical techniques surrounding integration and approximation in general. Really helpful stuff to help with theoretical knowledge
Dynamic programming and how to model various macro concepts in julia.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: The course content is interesting and useful, yet not too difficult. This felt like a survey course in the sense that we didn't delve too deeply into any method; rather, the professor introduced us to a wide range of tools and models and opened the door for us to explore more on our own time or future research. The problem sets and final project were fun and intellectually rewarding. I think I learned a lot despite the assignments not taking too long. The professor and teaching assistant were both very helpful and generous with their time. I can't think of any weaknesses for the course.

This course is very underrated! Professor Smith is great at explaining the math behind each method and walking us through Julia. I personally did not find any weaknesses (perhaps a bit more guidance on what is required in the final write-up?).

strengths: material is interesting and relevant, problem sets are helpful, Julia is a cool language, 
weaknesses: virtual lecture wasn't always easy to follow, we occasionally got a bit into the weeds in specific models

Great class and Professor and Anthony were both elite at the material and elite at explaining the material. Dont think I could have done this without their help and they really really made the material accessible. 

Only weakness is LOL the period of confusion between lecture and when I ask for help

The zoom format was challenging but I really enjoyed the class. Most of the learning in my opinion happens through the problem sets and final project so the experience with the class was still very good.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course ran as well as it could've given virtual learning. Professor Smith used a tablet as a blackboard and shared his computer screen whenever he wanted to walk through some code. Because this was primarily a lecture-based class, not much was lost because we weren't in person.
It was all very successful. The lectures ran super smoothly.
I liked the lectures done on notes. It allowed me to follow along at a much more reasonable pace then slides.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Of course! The professor is great, the assignments are fun, and the material is compelling. Most other economics courses at Yale don't offer exposure to this type of coding (in econometrics, for example, you're cleaning data or running regressions) or a similar level of quantitative rigor. I also imagine that the stuff you pick up in this class would come in useful in your first year of graduate school. Some of the models you learn are actually quite sophisticated and relevant to research that's going on now.

Yes, especially if one is interested in macro or finance research. Engaging lectures and problem sets help you learn fundamental methods and their applications to well-known models, and the final project is great for letting you explore a topic of personal interest.

I would definitely recommend this course if you want to learn a bit more about how you can apply programming in economics research. I will definitely use this in the future (whether it's for research or a thesis). I came into this course not really expecting anything, but I would say it's one of the Econ courses where I really got to learn how to implement things (as opposed to just solving math problems) and see how they worked.
Definitely, yes. The material is super interesting and important. You'll learn lots of relevant computational skills.
For sure. Take it as junior if you can because this will be helpful for thesis.
Yes, it was my favorite econ class at Yale by far and gave me the skills to actually start doing modern macro research.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A. All lectures were held live over Zoom, and all of them were recorded.
recorded lecture
Lectures were recorded and lecture notes (which were elite) were posted
Zoom lectures
